raw_text:
Robinson ready for difficult task
 
 England coach Andy Robinson faces the first major test of his tenure as he tries to get back to winning ways after the Six Nations defeat by Wales.
 
 Robinson is likely to make changes in the back row and centre after the 11-9 loss as he contemplates Sunday's set-to with France at Twickenham. Lewis Moody and Martin Corry could both return after missing the game with hamstring and shoulder problems. And the midfield pairing of Mathew Tait and Jamie Noon is also under threat. Olly Barkley immediately allowed England to generate better field position with his kicking game after replacing debutant Tait just before the hour. The Bath fly-half-cum-centre is likely to start against France, with either Tait or Noon dropping out.
 
 Tait, given little opportunity to shine in attack, received praise from Robinson afterwards, even if the coach admitted Cardiff was an "unforgiving place" for the teenage prodigy. Robinson now has a tricky decision over whether to withdraw from the firing line, after just one outing, a player he regards as central to England's future. Tait himself, at least outwardly, appeared unaffected by the punishing treatment dished out to him by Gavin Henson in particular. "I want more of that definitely," he said. "Hopefully I can train hard this week and get selected for next week but we'll have to look at the video and wait and see. "We were playing on our own 22 for a lot of the first half so it was quite difficult. I thought we defended reasonably well but we've just got to pick it up for France."
 
 His Newcastle team-mate Noon hardly covered himself in glory in his first major Test. He missed a tackle on Michael Owen in the build-up to Wales' try, conceded a penalty at the breakdown, was turned over in another tackle and fumbled Gavin Henson's cross-kick into touch, all inside the first quarter. His contribution improved in the second half, but England clearly need more of a playmaker in the inside centre role. Up front, the line-out remains fallible, despite a superb performance from Chris Jones, whose athleticism came to the fore after stepping into the side for Moody. It is more likely the Leicester flanker will return on the open side for the more physical challenge posed by the French forwards, with Andy Hazell likely to make way. Lock Ben Kay also justified his recall with an impressive all-round display on his return to the side, but elsewhere England positives were thin on the ground.
llama3.2:1b: Andy Robinson is facing a difficult task after England's 11-9 loss in the Six Nations.
He will be making changes to his back row and centre to try to get back on track.
Lewis Moody could return after missing with hamstring and shoulder problems, while Martin Corry might also make a return.
Mathew Tait is likely to start alongside Olly Barkley, who replaced him just before halftime.

Tait received praise from Robinson for his defensive work in the first half, but has been critical of himself for some errors, including a tackle on Michael Owen and fumbling Gavin Henson's cross-kick into touch.
The midfield duo of Mathew Tait and Jamie Noon are also under pressure to perform.
Andy Hazell is expected to make a return from injury on the open side, replacing Chris Jones in the line-up.
Lock Ben Kay has also justified his recall after an impressive all-round display in his previous appearance.
llama3.2:3b: England coach Andy Robinson faces a major test as he looks to bounce back from the Six Nations defeat by Wales.
Changes are likely in the back row and centre for Sunday's game against France, with Lewis Moody and Martin Corry returning after hamstring and shoulder problems.
Olly Barkley is set to start at fly-half.
Tait received praise despite being subjected to a tough debut, while Noon's performance was deemed inadequate.
The line-out remains a concern, but Chris Jones performed well in his first game back.

Olly Barkley may start at fly-half.
Mathew Tait and Jamie Noon received criticism for their performances, but they will need to work hard to be considered for next week.
England's line-out remains a concern despite Chris Jones' performance, and Andy Hazell is expected to make way for Lewis Moody.

He is expected to make changes to the back row and centre as he looks for a winning set-piece game with Wales.
Other players under threat include Mathew Tait, Jamie Noon, Olly Barkley and Ben Kay.
England's primary forward is Lewis Moody, who allowed the home team to score early on.
The best starting player remains Tait, though he faces pressure from Henson.
England are likely to lose their most valuable player, Ollie Blake, to injury after an injury to Tipton.

Oliver Barkley replaces Tait with an improved kicking game, while Tait remains under threat of being dropped despite praise from Robinson.
In the midfield, Tait is expected to start against France; it's uncertain whether either Mathew Tait or Jamie Noon will be selected due to their performance in Wales.
Robinson must decide between continuing his current team and seeking replacements before facing France on Sunday at Twickenham.

There's also speculation about Mathew Tait or Jamie Noon dropping out of the midfield due to Olly Barkley’s strong performance.
While Mathew Tait received praise despite limited playing time, Newcastle teammate Jamie Noon underperformed in his debut.
The line-out remains a concern, with Chris Jones performing well but likely to shift from the open-side.
Ben Kay also had an impressive return as a lock.
Overall, England faces tough decisions and lacks standout performances across positions.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Robinson ready for a difficult task  
England coach Andy Robinson is preparing for his first major test as he tries to return to winning ways after losing 4-13 in the Six Nations game.
He's making changes, especially in the back row and center, due to the recent loss.
He's considering withdrawing from firing decisions with just one game against Wales, though Tait was praised afterward despite being overlooked by Robinson because of his injury.
Tait is under pressure for France, starting at the flank with a possible dropout.
The team-mate Noon has shown improvement but missed a tackle on Michael Owen in the build-up to Wales' try.
England's defense showed promise early, so they need better playmakers inside the center role.
The front line still struggles despite Chris Jones' strong performance after stepping back for Moody.
Locks from Leicester are recalling, though England lacks positives elsewhere.
tinyllama:1.1b: England coach Andy Robinson will likely make changes in the back row and center ahead of the upcoming Six Nations match against France at Twickenham.
He will likely keep Mathew Tai and Jamie Noon, both effective kickers after replacing debutant Tai with a stronger lineup against Wales.
However, England's midfield duo of Olly Barklay and Matt Gaunton may be dropped or start against the French, given their limited opportunities in attack.
Despite Tai's impressive performance, Robinson still considers him as the future of English rugby, stating that he will look at training videos to pick up on certain aspects.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The article discusses the challenges faced by coach Andy Robinson in his quest to restore England's winning form after their Six Nations defeat by Wales.
England faces France at Twickenham Stadium.
Captain Martin Corry could return from a hamstring injury.
The midfield pairing of Mathew Tait and Jamie Noon is in jeopardy.
Olly Barkley is expected to start against France.
Gavin Henson was particularly harsh on Tait.
Robinson values the skills of a player like Tait, who can contribute from both the attack and the midfield.
Despite facing tough competition in the form of France, England coach Andy Robinson must adapt his tactics to find the winning combination.
Leicester flanker Chris Jones may start on the opposite side to that of Moody for a more physical challenge against the French forwards.
Outwardly, Tait seems unaffected by the punishing treatment he received from Gavin Henson but is apparently determined to train hard and improve his game for future matches.

Robinson may consider withdrawing him from the squad due to his young age, though Tait seems unaffected by his first game.
He wants more of that kind of play in future games and is hoping for a chance to train hard and get selected for the next week.
His teammate, Jamie Noon, also needs to improve his performance as he missed tackles, conceded penalties, and fumbled a cross-kick in his first major Test.
England's line-out remains weak despite Chris Jones' efforts.
The team may need more of a playmaker in the inside center role and someone with a more aggressive playing style in front of the goal.
